editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Amorous ORONTUS: OR The Love in Faſhion.
ACTUS I.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: HAſt done my Meſſage?

sp.speaker: Clinton.
sp.l: Yes, Sir,

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: And convey'd
My Letter to the hands of the fair Maid?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: To her own, Sir,

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: And ſhe, I'le warrant paus'd
E're ſhe would read the torments her eyes caus'd,
Would have return'd it coldly back,—and feign'd....

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Quite contrary,—Without being conſtrain'd;
Without demur's, or if's,—or And's,—or ſtops,
She read it thr'ough.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: This was above my hopes!
'Tis more then my fond heart could dare believe;
And ſhe ſcorns not, for ought I can perceive.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Cupid, with's keeneſt Shaft, her heart did hit,
And you have, this time, more Succeſs then Wit.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: 'Bove expectation!

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: In what you deſign'd,
You have the Tyde both for you, and the Wind:
You ſail in a ſmooth Sea, and may go far,
Unleſs ſome Rival-Pyrare prove a bar.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Thou know'ſt what Wracks my Veſſel's ſubject to.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: From all poor fears, here's that will ſecure you.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Letter for letter, Favour for
Favour.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: What hath ſhe anſwer'd?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Yes, Sir,—or
I'me much miſtaken,—for I long did ſtay,
Till this kind Paper brought me glad away.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Let's open't,—all my hopes I here ſhall ſee.
sp.stage: reads a line or two to himſelf.
sp.l: I wrote in Verſe, in Verſe ſhe anſwers me:
She's skil'd in all perfections the world knows.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Yes,—Ladies now can do't in Verſe or Proſe:
They handle any good—thing well of late;
So great perfection's in our Female ſtate.

lg.l: In barture of your Love, which you do prize ſo high
Orontus, you have dar'd preſume to ask me mine;
Tho I ſometimes admit of Love, indeed, yet I
Mean it ſhall coſt me nought, elſe I ſhould ſoon decline.
To give you heart for heart, ſuch an exchange would be,
No merit ever durſt aſpire ſo high before:
You proffer homage here, 'cauſe you my worth do ſee:
And I your ſervice own,—Why ſhould you whyne for more?
I ſhall not value yours, at any higher rate.
Can it be juſtly thought, your Love ſhould be more great;
Then let us caſt accompt exact without deceit,
That neither be Trapand and after, cry,—a Cheat!
If thoſe heart-renting ſighs, which you do breathe ſo oft,
Do flatter you with hopes, I ſhall your Sute approve;
Believe me, when I ſay, my breſt is not ſo ſoft;
Nor does a thouſand ſighs weigh one poor grain of Love.
How-ever let us try,—put your ſighs in one ſcale,
And in the other lay, the honour of my Chains,
Swear to abide the teſte,—if my weights chance to fail,
I'le add my heart thereto, and eaſe you of your pains.
Her Anſwer is as ſubtil as 'tis witty;
Such ſuperficial arrogancy's pretty.
This charming pride of her affected ſtile,
Throws as ſtrong Chains upon me, as her ſmile.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Your Song was ſhril, the Eccho anſwers loud.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Nor is it ſtrange to me, that ſhe ſeem's proud:
'Tis like to like, my Letter boaſted mine;
And ſhe in her's, makes her own Merits ſhine.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Strange, or not ſtrange, y'are paid in your own Art.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: It was the ſureſt way to take my heart.
Preſumption, in a Woman that begins.
To weild Love's Scepter, beſt her Subjects wins:
It ſpeaks her pow'r and grandeur, puts her Worth
Upon it's Throne; ſets all her Glories forth:
Teaching us, we muſt humbly wait below,
And e're a favour ſhe on us beſtow,
By fair degrees of ſervice, we ſhould ſtrive
Unto ſome height of Merit to arrive.
So 'tis no fault; brave Spirits count it none;
Or elſe they find it a moſt pleaſing one.
My humour's ſuch, that as I had before
Priz'd my ſelf much, I'de have her prize her more.
I like they ſhould, in a ſlight faſhion
Look coyly in Our new-born paſſion;
An ſhew us 'tis no eaſie task to win
The Fort, nor ſhould One ſummons let us in:
Thoſe that meet no reſiſtance on one part,
Not bravely gain, but poorly begg a heart;
And ſhe whoſe eaſineſs takes up no ſhield,
Rather to pitty does, then merit yield.
I ſcorn ſo tame a purchaſe,—for in ſhort
There moſt I love, where I have paid moſt for't.
All cheap Commodities I ſtill diſpiſe.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Strange Trader in theſe Love-commodities!
But Flora,—what of her?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: She's ill attended,
Her froward humour hath her Raign ſoon ended.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: And yet, Sir, you love to be roughly us'd?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Yes,—but provided I be not abus'd,
No Rival ſet above me;—Or if ſhe
Seem ſcornful, let her ſcorn ſtill noble be:
Let her reproach my want of worth or fame,
So to encreaſe, not quench the growing flame.
But Dorothea, though a while ſhe may
Diſſemble openly,—Her heart does ſay
In ſecret,—I do love:—Though ſhe deny
It to the world; 'tis womens policy
To appear nice.—So though ſhe'l not avow
Her heart ſubmits, I'm ſure ſhe loves me now.
The title of invincible's laid down;
I meaſure her thoughts as I do my own.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: No doubt, you think ſo,—You have Faith good ſtore,
And thanks to heav'n! one exc'lent Vertue more!
You ſtoop at all Game.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I!

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Yes, you,—pray be
Not Angry, for all this I know and ſee:
And is not this a Prize of great regard,
Part of One heart amongſt a thouſand ſhar'd?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Nay,—that's too many.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Reckon,—let me ſee.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Why, then i-faith, I've this day lov'd—but three—
And of thoſe three, that thou may'ſt be diſprov'd,
This being lovelieſt, Now—is only lov'd.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: If ſo, Nay then her fortune's very fair:
But three,—and—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Peace!—I ſpy Eraſtes there

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Something of moment leads him here apace.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: FRiend, I read Joy upon your tell-tale face.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: There's much more in my heart, I've got the day
Of a ſtern beauty; after much delay,
And fierce repulſes, my moſt faithful flame
Will crown me with her happy Bridegrooms name.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: What, have you lov'd and kept the fire ſo hid?

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: Diſcretion does diſcoveries forbid.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Yet, friendſhip ſomewhat claims.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: 'Tis very true,
It does, and warrants this addreſs to you,
Whereby I ſhall this myſtery unlock,
And give you the full knowledge, ere you knock
At my hearts cloſet.—Know, the Lady, then,
Whoſe love makes me the happieſt of men:
This morning as a favour ſent to me
A Letter,—which, although it dubiouſly
Does ſeem to ſpeak,—Yet nothing leſs then Love
Could dictate it, or her quaint Pen thus move,
For ſhe that writes in ſuch a pleaſant ſtile
Is yielding,—though ſhe parley yet a while.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: So that your courtſhip ſhall it's ends acquire?

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: Let me obtain of you but one deſire,
And it compleats my Wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Sir, to doubt
My readineſs would wrong me.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: Hear me out.
This Embaſſie's un-anſwer'd yet,—and will
Without aſſiſtance be un-anſwer'd ſtill:
'Tis writ in drolling Verſe, and ſuch a ſtrain
As does ſurpaſs the reach of my weak brain.
Pray write it for me.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Sir,—my former care
In often ſerving you, ſhall make me ſpare
All complement:—I never could deny
To do a friend ſo ſlight a courteſy.
I'le do't, and try my skill in Poetrie.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: This ſpeaks you noble, and obliges me.
Adieu.

div.head: ACT. I. SCEN. III.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: A Fine requeſt, i'faith I ſay.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Next this,—may I not hope himſelf, one day
Will come and court me, to make Love for him?
O, What a brave condition am I in!
Have I not reaſon confident to be
Of my own Sute, when ſuch crave help of me
To write Epiſtles:—What thinkſt thou of it?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Why, Sir, I think, if it be want of Wit
In him to ask, 'tis worſe in you to do.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Thou ſpeakeſt freely.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Shall I tell you true,
Now I perceive how wildly you engag'd
Your Talents for another, I'm enrag'd.
—When neer ſome Beauty, I oft hear you ſwear
Your heart's poſſeſs'd only by her,—though there
Are forty more, have more room there then ſhe
Whom you court only for Varietie;
Meaning with Complement her Wit to prove,
Or rather ſhew your own Wit, in the Love
You do but feign for paſtime.—Here, now I
Your Lies approve, cauſe for your ſelf you lie.
This I'm content with.—But when there's no end
Except the feeble int'reſt of a friend,
That you ſhould lye for them!—as if before
You had not ſins enough upon your ſcore!
For to ſay truth, how can you know his heart
That never knew your Own?—Yet on his part
You'l write he loves,—are you ſure this is truth?
May he not feign?—Yet you'l ſwear for this Youth.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I might have wav'd it very eaſily,
And any elſe had been deny'd;—But I
Knowing him Lucia's brother, One o'th' three
Whoſe almoſt equal Beauties tempted me:
And alſo knowing, he a neighbour dwels
Neer Dorothea, who ſomewhat excels
At preſent, 'cauſe moſt kind,—could not refuſe
Him, whom ſometimes as Brother, I may uſe,
Sometimes as Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: This was well fore-ſeen,
And a far off!

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: The dulleſt ſouls have been,
Sometimes moſt uſeful:—And 'twas this indeed
Made me ſo ſoon reſolve to help his need.
—But,—whilſt I talk, my Task I quite forget;
—Come,—let's examine how ſhe does him treat.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Perhaps ſhe jeeres him.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I dare ſwear't almoſt
Or if ſhe ſooths him 'twil be to his coſt.

div.stage: He opens the Letter Eraſtes left with him and reads.

q.l: In barture of your Love, which you do prize ſo high
Eraſtes you have dar'd preſume to ask me mine;
Sometimes I may admit of Love indeed, yet I
Mean it ſhall coſt me nought,—elſe I ſhould ſoon decline.

div.stage: He takes out his own Letter and confronts with this which Eraſtes left.
div.l: Have I took one for t'other?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Yes, ſure,—for Twinns are not more like each other.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: N'ere did my Opticks meet the like ſurprize;
'Tis word for word the ſame, if I have eyes.
—Nay,—having well examin'd,—Now I ſee
If mine's th' Original, this muſt Coppy be:
Both writ by the ſame hand i-faith....

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: And troth,
She finds one block doth fit the heads of both;
No matter though; Your Dorothea may
Diſſemble,—well gueſs'd,—Yet her Heart does ſay
In ſecret, (as this plainly now does prove)
ORONTUS IS THE ONLY SPARK I LOVE.
The Pride of her affected Lines,—you know,—
Was the beſt ſnare to catch your Heart,—for though,

l.hi: She ſeem'd to Drole with Love in a New ſtyle,
It was true Love did Dictate all the while.

sp.l: O!—Might I laugh before my Maſter now?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Do, I'le not hinder—preethe laugh on—do,
Laugh loud,—I'le laugh my ſelf,—and ne're be ſad.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Off with your Vizard,—why, it makes me mad
For your ſake;—And can you ſet this good face
On ſuch ill luck! Curſe her! for in this caſe,
Conſtraint will ſorrow ſwell.—Oh! 'tis moſt rare;
Good lord, Sir,—how contented you ſtill are!
A ſubtle Woer, Fox-like's full of Wyles:
But ſhe is ſubt'ler far, that him beguiles.
No Wit to Womans,—Where you thought to take,
Your ſelf's beguil'd.—This were enough to make
One hang himſelf,

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: 'Tis ſomewhat odd,—and I
Confeſs a Punie, might ſigh dolefully;
Then thump his breaſt, Void of experience;
Accuſe his ſquinting Planets influence▪
But, I, who underſtand the ways of Love,
Such trivial chances never ſhall me move.
If ev'ry object pleaſe,—What loſs is One?
I'm ne'r inſlav'd, my heart ſtill keeps it's own;
To give or take,—To gain or elſe to looſe,
Prepar'd;—Then at the leaſt Repulſe I chooſe
A new;—Nay whatſoever I proclaim
To them, I ſtill am Maſter of my flame.
Thus divers objects ev'ry day does bring
Freſh ſatisfaction to my Mind,—The thing
I ſolely aim at.—And let none explode
Me for't, tho it ſeem ſtrange,—'Tis a la mode▪

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Preſerve this humour, you may need it ſtill.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: My croſſes ne're ſunk deeper, nor e're will.
If one prove falſe,—mothers Love is ſure:
And I for every grief do find a eure,
Hence comes the gain t' have Miſtreſſes in ſtore.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Hylas, when living underſtood not more.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: His Fancy, tho differ'd from mine, for I
Love where I'm lov'd without inconſtancy:
But if their lightneſs make them in the end
Love change,—In troth,—I'm ſo much my own friend▪
I dare not harbour trouble in my breaſt;
But, without whyning, keep my heart at reſt,
By filling up, the vacant place again,
With new Ones,—So 'tis all one, ſhine or Rain.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Your heart at this rate yields a good Rent, Sir,

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: It does,—Now Luce has half,—I've given't her:
And ſuch as 'tis, there's many envy me.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: But why divided; good Sir, let it be
Intirely hers,—Or give her no room there,
Leaſt ſhe neglect your flame too,—for I fear
This Madam Lucia, tho as yet ſhe ſmile,
May like the other in the end beguile.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I have no cauſe to doubt this ſhould prove ſo;
Lucia did ſtill with judgment act, you know.
Her conduct's regular; ſhe's Modeſt, Wiſe,
Above the fears of paltry jealouſies.
I only find in her one grand default.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Why, ſhe loves Me, more then ſhe ought.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: A grand default indeed!

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: 'Tis I declare,
For Lovers quarrels ever Lovely are:
'Tis pleaſing when the object we doe love
Seems to ſuſpect our Vows, our faith to prove:
By this our int'reſt is more fortify'd,
Love's born a new, when newly juſtify'd:
So that whatever Storms ſuch doubts can breed,
The Calme's more ſweet, when Pardon does ſucceed.
And then, freſh Favours meeting in the cloſe,
Needs muſt th' accus'd gain, more then he can looſe:
But where a Lovers Wiſhes glutted are,
No Peace is made, 'cauſe there was never War.
A dull and ſated Lover, lives at's eaſe,
Serves but by habit, takes no thought to pleaſe;
Keeps the old Road,—but ſtrives for nothing new,
'Tis ever—You love me, And I love you.
Who would not hate that groſs and vulgar Trade?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Rare are the Obſervations you have made;
You ſtudy'd this Point well it does appear,

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: FRiend, I am happy thus to find you here,
I ſought you all about,

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: What would Florame?

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: Tell you the Secret of my Am'rous flame.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Some Love intrigue?

sp.speaker: Floram̄e.
sp.l: It is ſo,—I am now
Deſtin'd to Marriage by a Fathers Vow;
And though he found me irreſolv'd to this,
In ſecret it by him concluded is.
The Party's Gallant,—of a Noble Strain;
But,—Oh! another in my Soul doth Raign.
And whatſoever obſtacles ariſe,
My Heart's not mine, but while 'tis Lucia's prize.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Lucia's?

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: Ther's reaſon why you ſhould admire.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Ther's my brave Gallant out o'th' Pan i'th Fire.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: The old conteſt which from her brother parts
My company, might well divide our hearts.
But all ſuch ſlight impediments are vain,
T'oppoſe his Laws, who is ſole Soveraign.
Love by his Tyranny ſubdues us ſtill,
Summon we yeild; Obey, ask what he will:
Who as he liſt, tho blind and young, yet knows
When, and to whom our Hearts he will diſpoſe.
Thus ſpite of int'reſt, Love my hate diſmiſt,
Nor can I longer Lucias charms reſiſt:
Tho, to attain unto my wiſhed End,
Time is my greateſt hope, and ſureſt friend.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: That may alone her brothers hate ſubdue;
Time ſtranger things effects.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: It's very true,
I do expect that Miracle from it.
In the mean while, this Night the time is ſet
By Lucia's Maid, who at my Rendez-vous,
Upon a ſign, let's me into their houſe:
Where, by her ſweet converſe, ſhe'l bleſs my flame.
But, ſince the place ſuſpicious is,—I came
To beg your company,—Say? ſhall I ſpeed?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: You ſhall,—I never fail'd a friend at need.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: At your own home I'le call.

sp.speaker: Cliton.

l.hi: Above the fears of petty jealouſies:
Her Conduct's regular; and bating this
Grand fault, That ſhe too much your Lover is;

sp.l: She's exquiſite in other Qualities.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Now you'l repeat twenty new fooleries,

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: None other ever her eſteem could get.
Say, now, Sir, Does it make you ſtark Mad yet?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: So diſguiz'd, Sir, will you ever be?
Y'are Mad, I ſay, Or elſe the Dev'l take me:
Not Mad, and loſe two Loves both in one Day?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: This only ſets me a New Game to play:
And ſoon as e're Lucia or Doll, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: What you'l ſpeak to'um.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Yes, infalliblie:
I long to meet'um,—Then will I ſet forth
My Paſſion to the height of Zeal and Worth:
Firſt, ſhall my Sighs begin to charm their Ears▪
And if they fruitleſs prove,—I'le uſe my Tears:
Ten thouſand Sobbs, next, ſhall them entertain;
Yet all this while, my Heart ſhall feel, no pain:
Laſt, Death I'le ſummon too, for my redreſs;
Yet, Joy to ſee another them poſſeſs.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Tho ever with you, y'are above my ken.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Patience a while, thou't know me fully then.
In th'interim, this place is not ſo ill,
But I know where to play my Reſt on ſtill.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: And you think ſome will hear, and yet give eaſe?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Yes, Cliton, with much gladneſs, when I pleaſe.
Laſt night a certain Brown-Laſs took my Eye,
And was the object of my Gallantry
For a long ſpace, whilſt we walk'd in the cool
Shade of St. James's, where ſo much a Fool
I was to proffer her my Diamond Ring:
My new Acquaintance ſoon accepts the thing:
Tho all, I from this Beauty could command
Then,—Was to wait her home, and kiſs her Hand.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: And you went in?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: No,—ſhe for reaſons, then
Forbid,—but, bid me this day come agen.
It ſatisfy'd me, I her houſe did know;
Now ſhe expects my Viſit, and I'le go:
She might unkindly take it, ſhould I miſs.
Follow,—this Turning brings us where it is.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: E're you goe further, One word, good Sir, yet.
She's blithe?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Yes, wonderfull

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: And call'd?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Lyſet.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: March off, march off, your Viſit's at an end.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Raſcall.....

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: March off, I pray; None can pretend:
None has to do with her.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Sir, I know.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: She promis'd me this day.....

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: 'Twas craft, if ſo▪

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: You know her well, then?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Yes, too well for me,
She is my Miſtriſs, Sir, ſhe is my Shee.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: She has a Lady's Dreſs, and Garb.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: T' my ſorrow
Her pride confounds all I can beg, ſteal, borrow;
And having found my Purſe now ebb'd too low,
To ſerve a Lady, ſhe this day did go.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: What Lady?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: This night, Sir, ſhe will me tell.
Mean time,—changing your Courſe you would do well:
For if your hopes are all on Lyſet plac't,
Indeed 'twill prove, labour in vain, at laſt.
Your heart being vacant, therefore, you may hire
It out agen, to ſhe, ſhall firſt inquire.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Spite of the fatal ſhock, thy news does bring,
Soon ſhalt thou ſee't, well furniſhed agin.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: A thouſand new Ones, may ſolicite-yee,
But who believs't not, ſhall not damned be.
Pray vaunt not▪ though, your great skill any more;
This morn, you had three Miſtriſſes in ſtore;
A 〈…〉 all are gone!

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: 〈…〉 Judgment on appearance give.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Sir, you do well, yet upon hopes to live:
Troubles are light to thoſe thereon can feed.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: 'Twere ill done to reject hope in my need,
Since to regain the two firſt,—happily,
Suſpicion does combine with Jealouſy:
And to bring Lyſet to my Lure,—This Spell
Of Gold and ſparkling Jewels promiſe well.
Theſe oft work Wonders, more then you expect.
—But—ſtay,—Eraſte's Letter I neglect.
I muſt go home and Write.—Come.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Now I ſay,
If I know ought, you'l vanquiſh every way.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Let Time work out my Ends,—ſwear not at all;
Expect the Iſſue, 'Tis the End Crowns all.

div.trailer: The End of the Firſt ACT.

div.head: ACTƲS II.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: MEet my reſpects with ſo ſevere an Eye?

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: To you Florame, 'tis due ſeveritye.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: When will you treat with more compaſſion?

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: When you ceaſe off'ring me, what's not your own.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: My Love-ſick-Heart gains little, all this while.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: I'le not enrich my ſelf with others ſpoil.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: How ſhamefully you do my Faith ſuſpect.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Inconſtant men, no better can expect.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: What, have I dar'd ſome other Face adore?

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: It is not fit that I ſhould tell you more.
Tho indiſcreet our Sex eſteemed be,
Florame, I promiſed ſtrict ſecreſie.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: Some perſon near you does me an ill turn,
But all is vain againſt me,—ſtill I burn
For you, Dear Lucia, Heaven's my Witneſs, I,....

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: When I require, your ſelf then juſtifie.
Pray leave me now, for many eyes do ſee
Us here, and that may much diſcredit me.
More talk at preſent in this place may prove
Loſs to my Honour, No gain to your Love.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: This coyneſs quells my Joy's, and makes me griever.
Yet I obey,—but, What muſt I believe?

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: That I not cruel am, but ſtill preſerve
As much eſteem for you, as you deſerve.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: To this eſteem add but ſome Love withall.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Pretend to others right were criminall;
I told you that before.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: Would you ſpeak clear......

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: I do believe this may obſcure appear:
But if your ſoul herein it's troubles find,
Conſult but Dorothea t' eaſe your mind,
She knows the Miſtery,—Adieu. Exit.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: ALl's loſt!
Whence knows ſhe this intended Match, that croſt
My will ſo much, tho by a Father preſs'd?

sp.speaker: Lycas.
sp.l: Is ought ſo ſecret, it may not be gueſs'd?
It may be Dorothea brags through pride.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: No, ſhe the iſſue dreads too, on her ſide:
For if the troubles on her face ſpeak true,
Not Love, but duty makes her yield thereto.

sp.speaker: Lycas.
sp.l: What are your hopes, Sir, then?

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: Love ſtill, and dye,
Rather then Change ſhall ſtain my conſtancy.
My mournful Story yet may Lucia move.

sp.speaker: Lycas.
sp.l: True,—But—Where can you meet to tell your love,
And not be ſpy'd? Her Brother and you are
At enmity, ſo that muſt be a bar
To keep you from the houſe; And ſhould you meet,
Guided by Love, at Church, or in the Street,
The many Witneſſes at th'interview,
Would ſcarce oblige her to hear all from you,

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: All this I know, too well, and 'tis my grief:
Nor is it thus, I do expect relief.
Who can preſume, ſince this Denial, ſhe
Would openly give willing ear to me.
But, with great Preſents, I her woman late
Have brib'd, who now is my confederate,
And this night, th'rough a back door brings me, where
I'le haſt my Triumph, or my Doom to hear.
There in my Tranſports, at her feet, I'le lye,
And beg her Sentence, Or to live, or dye
So this night Love, or Hate ſhall me befriend,
If Love, it ends my griefs; Hate—life ſhall end.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: But,—ſhould your two hearts joyn to one intent,
How can you hope Eraſtes ſhall conſent?

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: Thoſe petty Quarrels, haſte does oft engage
Us in,—are beſt made up by Marriage.
Lycas, if I could bring it but ſo neer?

sp.speaker: Lycas.
sp.l: But—then again......

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: Thou But'ſt it every where.
Allow ſome hopes, at leaſt, with all thy talk.
Stay,—Who leads yonder Lady down this Walk?
It's Dorothea! Gods! let's ſteal aſide.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: THis pleaſant Walk ſhew's Nature in her Pride.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: About this time the Gentry uſe t' appear.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: This is their Rendez-vous, they all flock here;
Eſpecially thoſe Gallants, who each night
In telling their Amours take great delight▪
Which is to ſay, Lyſet, ſo many Lies.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Indeed, I think, th' are moſt but Rallaries,

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: True,—Here they come, and their Love-tales relate;
And I, like others, come to hear'um prate:
But,—So deceitful th'are, 'tis Loves diſeaſe!
Yet we muſt quit the World, or ſtrive to pleaſe.
For Beauty a ſad Ornament would prove,
Did it not others charm, and gain their love.
The ſweeteſt Features which a face adorn
Without this quality, lives but forlorn:
Like hidden Treaſures, they for nothing ſerve,
While Miſer-like, the rich, they pine and ſterve.
I have my Method, and I like it well,
I ſtudy to pleaſe all, if poſſible;
Endeavour by all means ſo fair to be
That they may like me well, and tell it me.
Thoſe prccious quality's I little prize,
Whoſe hidden Luſter dazles not all Eyes.
Not, that I am ſo eaſie to be wonn;
Whyning ne're moves me to ſoft paſſion.
Affected ſadneſs is a fruitleſs art;
Their ſighs do much more cool, then warm my heart
My Courage, Prompted by our Sexes Pride,
Makes me maintain th' advantage on Our ſide
By my imperious carriage, and ſome Scorn;
For knowing We to give men Laws were born,
I make thoſe feel the weight that wear my Chain▪
Impoſing on them, as their Soveraign.
Or if their griefs I flatter,—I neer ſtoop,
But make them court long for a little Hope;
And that's the grand reward they gain at laſt,
For all their Paſſion, and their Service paſt.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Strange kind of Method this muſt ſurely prove?

sp.speaker: Dorothea
sp.l: 'Tis now in uſe, and as we ought to Love.
If we bend ne're ſo little we expoſe
Our hearts to the proud Triumph of our Foes.
A flatter'd Lover ſwell'd with Victory,
Blots all Submiſſion out of Memory:
To keep him ſtill our ſlave, he muſt be croſt,
And frown'd upon,—Theſe Fetters off, he's loſt!

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: And with ſuch Empire you reſt ſatisfy'd?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: I ſhall confeſs,—what yet ſome ſhame would hide.
But ſince one day gains thee ſo much good will,
Hear all diſcreetly,—but be ſecret ſtill.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: If one day be too ſhort my Faith to try,
More time ſhall make good my fidelity,
And ſhow your ſecrets ſafe with me remain.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Then know—That men are now become ſo vain,
That for this Month,—nay more I might have ſaid,
Hardly three Lovers have me Homage paid.
Of theſe, The one wooes me to be his Wife;
Which I ſo fear, it makes me hate my life;
My Father for Florame, conſent would get;
The man I prize for wealth, for Meen, for Wit:
But whatſoever Plea's Hymen can bring,
I dread that Slave, that ſhould become my King!
Next,—ther's Eraſtes a brave Gallant, whom I
Think for a need, for conſtancy would dye.
But,—he ſo out of Mode and Courtſhip is,
He may compare with any Amadis.
'Tis true,—ſince that, Orontu's late defeat
Makes his low Triumph up, he's ſo compleat.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: That Blade your ſervant?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Is he known to thee?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: I've heard him prais'd.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: O! how he pleaſes me!
An Air ſo noble, Garb ſo full of ſtate;
So gay a Humour, ne're importunate.
His Voyce ſo charming, his Converſe ſo rare,
Speaking ſo well, yet Writing better far.
His glory all to his own Vertue owes,
Knows his great Worth, not proud of what he knows.
Somewhat for him I feel,—more then I'le tell,
And would he ſtill ſigh for me it were well.
Although I dearly love to keep my heart,
I might at length reſolve with it to part.
From whence, judge what condition I am in.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: One of theſe Tickets, came not then from him?
Since you neglect to read it all this while.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Give me'um, Lyſet, and prepare to ſmile.
(Which juſt deliver'd as from home I came
I had not time till now to read the ſame.)
And though Orontus is concern'd i'th' jeſt,
It well deſerves our laughter, I proteſt.
He and Eraſte's here ſend their Loves;—And troth
'Tis the ſame Letter they do Anſwer both.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: 'Tis an accident may breed delight.
This morning I did to Orontus Write;
When finding it would fit the other,—ſtraight
(Glad to oblige him at ſo cheap a rate.)
I did Tranſcribe it, without more ado,
And ſo diſpatch'd him with that Coppy too.
What Anſwer, now, his ſlender Wit does give
I long to read.
Ha! Verſes, as I live!
I knew not he could Rhime.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Some end's of Playes.
Or Leaves dropt from old Poets wither'd Bayes.
Wherewith each youngſter now does Deck his head;
To be on all occaſions furniſhed.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.q: Tranſparant Beauty, whoſe moſt open Heart!
sp.l: That's ſuch a conjuring Phraſe it makes me ſtart!
sp.q: Your Soul unto the bottom makes me ſee.
sp.l: 'Tis well begun,—Ridiculous Poetrie.
But leave that there,—The other I'le peruſe;
Orontus, Anſwers with a ſmoother Muſe,
And I dare wager, e're I look there-on
Each Line will claim our Admiration.
How different from that his ſtyle will be?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: How well this thought of his Tranſparancy?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Then 'tis good and new,
If wiſe Orontus uſe Tranſparant too.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Ha! what have I got here!
This ſpeaks the ſame!

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: I think 'twill ſo appear.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: No matter, I'le ſee all; let us compare;
Read you Eraſte's, this will ſhew what they are.

lg.l: TRanſparent Beauty, whoſe moſt open heart
The bottom of your Soul does make me ſee,
Now I confeſs, of me you have the start,
Since in your breaſt my Heart lives doubtfullie.
I thought it ſhould have found it's Palace there,
Where you did mean to treat it as your King;
But I have mourn'd, ſob'd, ſigh'd, dropt many a Tear,
And ſtill have languiſh'd without profiting.
Yet will I not account at all with you,
What you propound will be but to your ſhame:
Should you for ev'ry ſigh, and ſhow'r that's due,
Stand debtor, it the Reck'ning would inflame.
My dolefull Sighs do ever make you ſmile.
Tho like a Tempeſt in my breaſt they throng:
Your Heart my weights diſdains; take heed the while,
Light as they are, th' out-weigh not yours e're long.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: This was deſign'd,—it does appear, too plain;
And 'tis Orontus only laid this Train.
Eraſtes is too dull.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: I'm of that mind:
But, now what difference of ſtyle d'ye find?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Well, this ſame day without much more ado • —
But, Gods!—My Fathers here!

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Orontus too,
With him.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: He knows thee not,—then preethe ſtay,
Whilſt I aloof watch till he goes away;
Then when the old man going hence you ſee,
Speak to Orontus, that he ſtay for me.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.stage: pulling her Hood over her face.
sp.l: She leaves me here a pretty Part to Act.

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: IN fine, I've paſs'd my word for the Contract▪
With Dorothea; and by Hymen ſhe
Muſt to anothers Will ſubjected be.
In th' interim, it ſeems, you love her well,
And near my Houſe oft ſtand as Sentinel:
A neighbour notes it, and does ſeem to ſcoff
At your vain Love,—Pray therefore break ſhort off.
The honour had been mine, if you, dear friend.
My ſon had prov'd; but now, you can't pretend.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: If by your houſe I ev'ry day appear,
A hundred others I oft ſpeak wit 〈…〉 ere
Of Love, and they are no mean Beauties, too.
But to explain.....

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: I know they talk how you
Love Lucia ſtill, our neighbour; but ſince we
So tender of our Credit ought to be,
Pray do not force me, Sir, againſt my choice▪
By ſuch deportment to make further noiſe.
Only forbearing eight days to appear,
Would ſtifle all the Whiſpers you bred here.
Adieu,—Pray ſtudy to give this content. Exit.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: A fair Remonſtrance, and to good intent.
How many Viſions, does that age attend?

div.head: ACT II. SCEN. V.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: SSſt Ssſt...
My Cavalier, turn this way friend.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Who calls me?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis I,—do you not ſee?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: An Envious Cloud eclipſes you from me.
This Hood to me, does a ſtrange torment prove;
Should we Act thus? We, who each other Love?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: A pretty Complement, and ſhows much wit;
We Love each other then?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: No doubt of it.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Well, I believ't for once,—ſince you ſay ſo,—
And ſure our equal Merits bred it;—Tho—
Till now I ignorant hereof did live.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Nay I my ſelf this ſcarcely yet perceive.
But Love's Almighty Power, as 'tis ſaid,
E're we can think on't, does our hearts invade.
And grant this Maxime true, you muſt allow't,
We may each other Love, Yet hardly know't.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: You never want a paint to make all fair:
But e're this time I knew, Sir, what you were;
And how your beſt Affection moſt times is
Subject to caution;—But to clear all this,
Am I deceiv'd?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Is't thou? ah! ſweet Surprize!
Lyſet, how Heav'n does this day bleſs my Eyes!
To meet thee I eſteem ſuch bliſs,—that—

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: .....ſoft.
I know what fuel heats your breaſt too oft:
Hear but my haſty Meſſage, e're you ſtir?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: A Meſſage, and from whom?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l:
Your Miſtriſ •
▪ Sir.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: 'Tis then from thee▪

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: That's good,—but I muſt tell
How Dorothea.—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: O, I know't full well.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Permit.—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: No, no, your cauſe of plaint I ſee,
You think her Beauty only Captives me;
But n're all-arm thy ſelf, nor credit it.
I value leſs her Beauty, then her Wit.
Her counterfeited Graces leſs then theſe,
Whilſt thou art worth fifty ſuch Dorothoe's.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: You think to jeer me thus,—but really,
I'm worth another, that's leſs worth then I

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Thy Eyes have gain'd ſuch pow'r on me this day,
That—

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: I believe, yet more then you would ſay.
And will not now diſſemble, you ſhall ſee't.
For tho ſome Features here may ſeem leſs ſweet:
Yet, hath my face enough to breed delight,
And more inclines to tempt, then to affright.
This Air, nor Port is like a Common Clown:
And I'm like ſome body, when my Hood's down.
Look!

div.stage: She ſpies Cliton coming and pulls her Hood over her Face.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Thy gay humour makes thy Face more fair.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: IS't not my Maſter with my Goſſip there?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: What will he ſay, if Cliton know 'tis I?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: He ſhall let go his Prize, or tell me why.

sp.speaker: To Orontus.
sp.l: Quick, Sir, Quick, Quick,—lord, I am out of breath.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: What ailſt?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Sir, they are gone into the field of death.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Who?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: They will fight unleſs your ſuccour come.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: What are they?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Florame and Eraſt.—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I run.
A Moment brings me back.

sp.speaker: Cliton, to Lyſet.
sp.l: —Gipſey! muſt you,
Becauſe new cloath'd, play with theſe Feathers too?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Come, Cliton, come, their ſteps let's follow.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: —Sir,
One is enough.—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Come!

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Not I,—I'le not ſtir.
Should we be forc'd to draw.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Rogue,—muſt I drive?

sp.speaker: Cliton, to Lyſet.
sp.l: You ſcape it fair, I'le teach you how to live.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: His anger he will hardly long refrain.
But,—Wher's my Miſtriſs, ſhe comes not again?
I'le ſeek her out, and know what ſtops her there. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.stage: Enters from the other ſide of the Theater, her Hood down.
sp.l: NEither Orontns nor Lyſet appear?
What ſtrange capricious Fate guides me this day?
A Father frights me hence,—Who, when away,
By ſome miſtake, I cannot apprehend.
Orontus, he, vouchſafes not to attend.
—But he returns.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: RAſcal, if e're again.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: But, Sir, if Lucia.—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: But's, and if's, are vain.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: What then? could I think that you could devine
She'd this night ſee y' at Window,—by a ſign?
And if I had not thus all-arm'd you, what—

sp.speaker: Orontus
sp.l: And why not ſtay?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: So I might have forgot:
You know my Memory's ſhort, and will forgive.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Peace!,—ſtay you there.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: May I theſe eyes believe?
The Slut yet waits him? ſhall I ſuffer all!

sp.speaker: Orontus, to Dorothea.
sp.l: Excuſe that heat, which you blind Zeal might call.
The Allarm was falſe,—And I return once more
To ſwear I dye for you,—whom I adore,
To tell you Dorothea needs muſt be
An object of diſdain, whilſt I know Thee:
For ſhe's ſo dull a Beauty, I ſcarce come
Into her ſight, but I am like to ſwoon.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: The devil a word before me, ſhe can find!

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: This ſevere ſilence ſhews you too unkind:
And without much more cruelty beſide,
You cannot ſtill your Beauteous Face thus hide.
Should my weak eyes grow dazled with the light,
I muſt.—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Take heed you faint not at the ſight!

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Madam, is't you?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Became your Hate you ſed.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Ha!—Ha!—Why, Lyſet's Metamorphoſed!

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Heav'n knows.—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: It knows, but what it ought to know;
I ſee, but what I thought to ſee;—And ſo
You now appear, but what you ſhould appear,
A groſs Deceiver, ſuch I find you here.
This at your birth, your Sex by oath, doth ſeal.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I from your Judgment juſtly might appeal:
But if ſometimes, th' effects belie our hearts;
Frequenting much your Schools we learn thoſe arts.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Should I relate; or weigh your lightneſs well.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Perhaps, ſome truth's we might each other tell:
But I'le ne're mind what anger now brings forth:
You know what ſuch a man as I am worth,
Speak not of hate, nor lightneſs,—wave ſelf-ends;
Let's quit each other, and become good friends.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Shall I forget ſo ſoon your late affront?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: You run the hazard elſe, to loſe more on't.
Should you refuſe 't agree,—I'le tell thee plain,
It would be hard to wooe me back again.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: 'Twere fit, indeed, that I ſhould ſatisfy.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: When I do proffer Peace thus handſomely.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: My anger juſtly does revenge purſue.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I have ſome reaſon to complain of you.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Yes, witneſs what your late Diſcourſe did ſay.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: And witneſs alſo what you Wrote to day.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: You thought to Court another to my ſhame.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: You, with your double Letter mock'd my flame.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Do not object, that harmleſs Plot, whereby
I of your weakneſs made diſcovery:
Believing that betwixt Eraſt and you,
Nothing was hid; I try'd and found it true:
Whoſe vanity, and poor injuſtice did
Bring that to light, which elſe, had yet lyen hid.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: And I, ev'n now, did rude diſdain expreſs,
Not but I knew to whom I made addreſs:
But purpoſely diſſembling, lay at watch,
To ſhew you oft Deceivers meet their match:
And that if you the Trappan did intend,
I would be ſure to fit you in the end.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Th' Excuſe is cold enough.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Examine yours.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: But your late carriage your great Crime aſſures.
Which Lovers Laws call Treaſon 'gainſt their State;
So that your guilt deſerves no more debate.
To ſatisfie my Honour 't ſhall ſuffice,
I baniſh you both from my Heart and Eyes;
And yet am milder then thoſe Laws were meant.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: We ſhall reſolve upon this baniſhment.
—But,—by ſo great a Subjects loſs we may
Foretell, your Empire quickly will decay.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: I'le rais't agen, take you no care for us.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: 'Tis but your intereſt makes me ſpeak thus.
In fine, I love you, and have no deſire
But to obey your will, till I expire.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Who ſhall ſecure this?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: You, if you will hear.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Let's know then wherefore you ſo ſcornful were?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Our Innocence is ne're ſo manifeſt
As—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: This night, at my houſe, I'le hear the reſt:
And to confirm your fair intents,—expect
Your due ſubmiſſion joyn'd with true reſpect. Exit.
Adieu.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: This ſtrange retreat does much ſurprize,

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Upon the point to yield, away ſhe flies:
Believing it were better ſtay till night.
—But,—I begin to find what caus'd her flight;
Eraſte's coming hither, drove her hence.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes, to Orontus.
sp.l: FRiend, may I ſpeak to you with confidence?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: You know me.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: I have partly likewiſe known
Florame is late a ſecret Lover grown:
And I, for weighty reaſons, fain would come
To find the object of his Martyrdome.
Now, ſince to watch him ſtill, might trouble breed,
Do not refuſe aſſiſtance at my need.
He haunts, and Loves you, and can never hide
That long from you, which is his joy and pride:
Pray, in my favour, ſeek to dive into't.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I'le go, juſt now, and try if I can do't.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: Adieu,—I'le leave you then. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: IS't your Will, Sir,
He know, Florame's Lucia's Idolater?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: No,—but to meet Florame,—fright him,—and ſay
Her Brother knows, he burns for Lucia.
—This night,—thou ſay'ſt, Fair Lucia does expect
My coming; Now, if ſhe through fear, ſuſpect
Eraſtes watches him,—Keeping away,
I ſhall have freedom what I pleaſe to ſay.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: But t'other Rendez-vous,—How goes that on?
For Dorothea looks.—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Let me alone
And, Cliton, thou ſhalt find things order'd ſo,
Had I a hundred,—I through all would go.

div.trailer: The End of the Second ACT.

div.head: ACTUS III.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: NOt one word now,—What Melancholly's this
Lock's up thy folly, which ſo pleaſing is?
I here thee ſigh, and oft bemoan thee, too.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Ah! Sir,—why am I not content like you?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Truly,—being freed from waiting on Florame,
Who dares not go, where ſummon'd by his flame?
I'm very well content, my Fortune's ſuch.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: I wiſh that I could likewiſe ſay as much.
But,—a ſtrange Malady does me attaque.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: My honour's Hypocondriaque.
And this ſo much the more torments my heart,
'Cauſe few to Cure our Honour have the Art.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: That I believe;—But ſay, Where didſt it get?
Art angry, 'cauſe thou ſee'ſt me ſerve Lyſet?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Not becauſe you ſerve her, I'le tell yee true;
But I'm diſpleas'd more, becauſe ſhe ſerves you.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Fool, doſt not thou, thy own advantage ſee?
Whilſt ſhe receiveth homage thus from me,
Her Merits in an higher Orb do move,
My Paſſion more enobling thy mean Love.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: That's it,—I fear,—leaſt by your courtſhip—I—
Receive my Patent of Nobility!
I've no ambition for it;—I confeſs,—
I ſhould do well without ſuch Nobleneſs.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: So great a Favour, you but ill repay.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: You do for me, much more, then I do pray.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Go, never grieve thy ſelf, e're a Week's ſpent,
Perhaps, I may leave her, to thy content:
That time may Wonders work, to ſatiate Me,
And then I'le prove no obſtacle to Thee,

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Mean while,—t' oblige me, till that happy day
You will my Sove Enoble, Sir, you ſay.
I ſhall be much engag'd.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: More then I'le tell.

sp.speaker: Cliton,
sp.l: The favour will deſerve the Chronicle.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Cliton, I'le tell thee, without Raillery,
Lyſet has Charms would tempt the chaſteſt Eye;
Whoſe Beauty I above all elſe prefer,
She having all, a heart can wiſh, in her:
So that believe me, I deal modeſtlie,
To borrow her, only eight days of Thee.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Since you ſuch treaſures find there, if you will
But give me double wages, keep her ſtill.
As well, I'm quite diſguſted with her now:
And you have puff'd her ſo with Pride,—I vow
Out of meer Scorn, the Baggage, when I came,
Forgot, or would not tell, her Miſtriſs name▪

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Villain, how dar'ſt thou ſo prophane to be,
As to miſ-name who's Worſhipped by me?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Pardon me Sir;—But though ſuch honour's due
To this new Saint, thus fam'd for—bleſſing you.
And though at ſuch a height ſhe now doth ſtand,
I muſt not ſpeak, but with my Cap in hand:
—If in ſome Houſe alone, we chance to meet,
Or Fortune lead me to her in the ſtreet,
May, I not then—with all humility,
And thoſe reſpects due to her quality,
As a return of thanks, for what I hear,
Give her in Love, one or two Cuffs oth' Ear?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Conſult with Reaſon, then—what that ſays, chuſe.
—But, here's the place of my two Rendez-vous.
And, if I am not much deceiv'd,—See there!
Lucia does at her Windore now appear.
Oh! how ſhe pleaſes me!

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: But—Lyſet more?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Not for the preſent.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Wondring I'le give o're!
Why—butfair Dorothea?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Leſs then ſhe.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Then cannot I gueſs, what your heart can be.
Juſt now.—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: 'Tis thus,—I love for Recreation,
And ſeldom feed on bare Imagination.
The greateſt Beauty, be it ne're ſo bright,
Tempts me no more, as ſoon as out of ſight;
A thouſand lovely Charms, may wound me,—when,
In thirty paces all is heal'd agen.
The preſent Beauty, tho inferiour far,
Makes me forget the Sun, t' adore a Star:
And ſince what ever object does me move,
Is lov'd by me, only out of ſelf-love;
It leaves my heart to all Impreſſions free,
And ſhe ſtill faireſt ſeem's, whom laſt I ſee.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Then Lyſet ceaſing in your Eve t' appear?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: The next I meet,—will pleaſe me more—I'le ſwear.
But I muſt go, and with an Am'rous Tone,
Tell Lucia that my heart loves her alone.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: But whilſt you tune your Tongue to ſpeak her fair,
Do you remember that you Jealous were?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Thou mak'ſt me timely recollect my part.
I' • o ſhape my ſpeech with a Complainants art.

sp.speaker: Orontns.
sp.stage: calling up to Lucia at the Windore.
sp.l: ARe you there Madam?

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Is't Orontus?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Who ſhould reproach your Infidelity,
Did I not think you were ſo juſt withal
Net to condemn, were I not criminal.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Orontus, this Allarm, ſhows very ill.
Can I betray you?—I not love you ſtill?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Oh! do not think that I ſhall dare complain:
My Tongue ſhall with reſpect its griefs refrain!
And though, that muſt encreaſe my ſuff'rings too,
Yet they are welcome, 'cauſe they come from you.
I glory'd to poſſeſs your Heart;—but then
Not being worthy,—you reſume't agen.
Now from your Mouth the Sentence I would hear,
And ſacrifice what I do hold moſt dear.
Happy,—if ill Succeſs no crime you deem,
And ▪tho I loſe your Love, keep your Eſteem

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: What killing Accents do your Lips expreſs!
Raving of Crimes, and of Unhappineſs!
Oh! do not hold me longer in ſuſpence;
But pray, unfold this Riddles dubious ſence.
And that your Moans, may Cauſe or Colour ſhew,
Declare this guilt, and this Misfortune too.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: A Rival's entertain'd in ſecret, Lo
That's my Miſ-hap,—my Crime I do not know
Yet I muſt ſay,—ſince you love him, and hate
Me,—I'm as Guilty as Unfortunate:
For to ſuſpect you of injuſtice, I
So hainous hold, I ſhould deſerve to dye.
Oh! lay the cauſe, then, of your Change on me
Which muſt bejuſt, tho I no reaſon ſee.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: This ſtrange Reproach puts me into a maze.—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Ah! why ſhould Miſery meet ſuch delays!
Torments are but encreas'd, that are defer'd.
Say, then, a Nobler Rival is prefer'd;
That my Defects adds glory to his name,
That his bright Luſtre, dimm's my dying flame.
That to inform me of this choice, you here
For the laſt time ſummon me to appear:
While, afterwards, to end this Amorus ſtrife,
In abſence, I muſt linger out my life.
'Tis too ſevere, will Love-ſick Judges ſay,
Yet, tho I periſh Lucia, I'le obey:
With ſo much care, that my ſad preſence ſha
Ne're mind you of your firſt-faith's Funeral

sp.speaker: To Cliton, aſide.
sp.l: Did I Act well my Part?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Rarely, indeed!
You'd make a quaint Comedian for a need.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: This Story ſo confounds me, to ſay true,
I ſcarce have Reaſon left to anſwer you.
Nor can I plead my Faith to juſtify,
Which you accuſe, but nothing ſpecify:
—Yet, if I freely may declare my ſence,
Your grief Orontus ſpeaks ſuch Eloquence
That I believe it leſs;—how e're it hit,
A Real grief, then wantonneſs of Wit.
A Lover, who with real ſorrow's ſtrook,
Uſes no Rhet'rique but a Dying Look.
Waves all fine words, No Advocate will Fee,
Only deep Sighs whiſpers his Miſerie.
Yet, if you know, I thus ungrateful prove,
Name me this Rival that uſurps your love?
Leave nothing to Evince my breach of Faith:
Declare what Favours he received hath.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Thoſe boſome Secrets, long may keep at home
If they muſt be conceal'd till Florame come.
Who, though he fondly hugg his paſſion,
This night will fail your aſſignation.
Some Remora, unlookt for, keeps him hence;
To morrow, you may know the conſequence.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: So, ſo, 'tis this begets your Jealouſie,
Florame was this night to have met with me?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: He's raviſht with the Joy he feels within!

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: You heard this from himſelf,—no doubt?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: —From him:
But, ah!—how far would your blind Rigour go?
Muſt I have ſeen your Heart yield to my Foe?
Was't not enough to ſatiate him with bliſs;
But to Damn me, too, I muſt witneſs this?

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Since your Suſpicions have no Wyles refus'd.
You little merit to be diſabus'd.
And any other, after ſo great wrong.—
But—ſtay—I ſee a Man ſure come along,
I'le change my Note, for 'tis my Brother's come.
My Brother is not here, Sir, he's from home.
Nor do I know exactly, to ſay right
At what time he's us'd to return at Night.
'Tis often late,—Wherever he does go.
Adieu.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: What Counter-talk?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: 'Tis pleaſant—tho.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: The more I ſtudy, leſs I apprehend.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Y'are crafty,—yet ſtill over-reach't i'th' end.
They find you but diſſemble—and ſo forth.
And here they plant ye, juſt for what y'are worth.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Peace! here comes one.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: WHo's there.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: —Orontus's Friend
Florame.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: The worſe for me, ill luck's attend.
What make you here,—had we not late agreed
That—

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: 'Tis but Curioſity, indeed.
A certain Fancy guided me this way,
Without deſign to ſpeak with Lucia.
—But,—ſure, I heard ſome one bid you adieu.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: What deſign makes me, here meet with you
Thus late.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: My great deſire to meet Eraſte
And eaſe your Mind, tranſported me with haſte,
Being confident, how e're he doubts your Love,
A little talk, would all his Fears remove.
But this my diligence is fruitleſs grown,
His Siſter telling me, hee's ſtill in Town.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: Do not deny I Love,—ther's ways enough,

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: I am thinking.

sp.speaker: Orontus, to Cliton aſide.
sp.l: Cliton, there's it now!
Lucia Loves Florame, and t'avoid being caught
She ſpying him, feign'd, I her Brother ſought.
Inconſtant Sex,—Who can rely on ſuch?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: The beſt of them, indeed, are not worth much.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: To fix his thought's ſome other way,—I'le chuſe
Rather fair Dorothea's Name to uſe▪
Tell him, 'tis Love ofher feeds my deſire.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: What can that do?

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: Much, if he ſhould inquire.
He may diſcover, how I ought to Wed—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: —Her,—is't She's deſtin'd to your Nuptial Bed?

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: The ſame.—Now judge, if this be not the way.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Friend, they from Lucia's can hear all we ſay:
Let's go from hence, I'le ſpeak my Mind elſewhere.

sp.speaker: Cliton, to Orontns apart.
sp.l: You'l miſs your ſecond Rendez-vous—I fear,
Think on it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Take you no care thereof,
E're I go twenty ſteps, I'le ſhake him off. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: THis muſt diſcover,—be he falſe, or true.
But,—how—he ſtay's

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: The Door ſtands open too,
And from above, the Light will guide his Eye.
Do you believe hee'l come, or elſe paſs by?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: If he want Innocence to plead his Cauſe,
He may—

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: If Mute, then hee's condemn'd by th' Laws.
H'as too much Wit to want's Apologie.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: What ſaid he, Lyſet,—When he talk't with thee?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: For you he languiſht, and for you did look:
And, I believe he wilfully miſtook.
What do you think?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: I know no more then you.
But—hee's excuſable if he ſpake true.
If he plaid falſe,—'twas manag'd with ſuch Wit,
That I do long to ſee th' Event of it.
In th' interim, not knowing what will be,
My heart affects only Neutrality.
—But the Door creaks.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Orontus,—Never fear▪

sp.speaker: Dorothea▪
sp.l: Shut the Door after him, that none may hear.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: To ſee me with her, will his thoughts perplex.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: MAdam, The greateſt glory of your Sex—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: What brings you hither with ſo bold a Face.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Here's work indeed!—a wrong man takes his place!

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: Finding the Door not ſhut, you talking by,
At that ſweet Voice, Love lent me wings to fly.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: We wait my Fathers coming home,—and ſee
You haſte away, or elſe you Ruine me:
He's hard by,—pray be gone.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: My Joy,—and Sorrow!
Alas—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: O! Keep alas, Sir▪ for to Morrow.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: What!—No compaſſion?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Yes,—towards my ſelf,
My Honour elſe is wrack'd upon this Shelf.
Time preſſes,—go, go forth pray,—'tis my will
Sure, you were born to perſecute me ſtill!
Will you for ever gaze,—and not reply?

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: O! Spell my Sighs,—and read my weeping Eye!

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: 'Tis not the ſeaſon now to count your tears
When pity has reſign'd my heart to fears.
Pray, Sir, haſte forth▪—look warily before—
But 'tis too late,—ah! me! Hee's at the Door
He Knocks, where will ye go?—there's no way forth.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: I'm ready, if you pleaſe, to meet his wrath.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Rather a thouſand times.—

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: To prevent all
I'le lead him to the Garden, th'rough the Hall.
There he's ſecure. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Th' advice is good I'le ſwear.
Go,—open as you paſs.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: CLiton, ſtay there.
sp.stage: Orontus Enters, leaving Cliton at the door.
sp.l: What,—is all vaniſh'd? this ſeems ſtrange to me,
I heard much noiſe,—yet can no body ſee!
To uſe me thus, is ill, I tell you true,
I neither came to ſcare,—nor hinder you.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Surely yo've taken me to task, this day.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: No,—but free humours hate ſuch boe-peep play.
And 'tis my trouble, that with ſo much care
You ſhould diſguize your ſelf from what you are.
What ever Gallant 'tis,—let him come forth:
My Paſſion dares all Eyes, to try its worth.
Nor ſhall my Zeal wax leſs on ſuch a ſcore,
I love a Miſtriſs, all men do adore.
And I had little hopes in this Eſſay,
Should I not court you, now, in your own way.
Variety's the Heav'n of your bliſs;
Then muſt I cheriſh what your Humour is.
Did I oppoſe the Freedom you like beſt,
That were to ſeek mine, not your Intereſt:
And would pervert the nobleſt ends of Love;
Inſtead of Subject, I ſhould Tyrant prove.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: A neat evaſion, made to this intent,
By taxing me, to ſhew you innocent.
This is ſmart Policy,—worthy your fame.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: So mild a Cenſure, cannot be your ſhame.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: This good opinion of me's noble too.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I find you act, but as you ought to do.
The beſt of Men have not a hope ſo vain,
E're to confine you in a ſhorter Chain;
They, from all parts in throngs to you do preſs,
Whilſt you alone ſhare out their happineſs.
Were not this glory then, diminiſhed,
Should you heap all theſe Favours on One head?
So great a Treaſure, ſuch a plenteous Feaſt,
Was never, ſure, meant for one Miſer gueſt.
For, tho, I do adore, what is ſo rare,.
And favour crave,—yet not above my ſhare.
I'le not aſpire, (tho in your flames I burn)
T' injoy you ſolely,—I'le but take my turn.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: What means all this, ſpeak plain and tell me true?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: That here,—ſome ſecret Rival courted you.
And if you further conference deſire,
I would not hinder,—but ſhall ſoon retire.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: This weak ſuſpicion is the Child of fear.
That any other.—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I've a faithful Ear,
That perfectly diſcerneth every Voice.
If.—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt like,—this time was a fit choice,
And you no promiſe had to day before?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Oh! you have Wit can go th'rough this and more.
Who with one Letter Anſwer's two,—Allow's
One night's enough t' exalt as many Vow's.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Your falſe conjectures, then, are rais'd from thence.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: No, no, I ſpeak on clearer Evidence.
Knocking at Door,—ſome noiſe made me begin
To doubt whether 't might pleaſe, ſhould I come in:
Some I heard walk and ſpeak, and midſt the noiſe,
Unleſs I'm much deceiv'd, I heard a voice
Say, There he's come, What ſhall we do with this!
Yet, I'le believe but what your pleaſure is.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: This I ſhould ne're endeavour to confute,
Did it not ſtick ſome ſhame on my Repute;
But really to undeceive you, know
That having bid my Woman wait below,
Whilſt I above ſtood as my Father's ſpy.—

sp.speaker: Lyſet Enters.
sp.l: But here ſhe comes will clear the Miſtery.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Come hither Lyſet.

sp.speaker: Orontus,
sp.l: Gods, what is't I ſee!
Lyſet ſerves here!

sp.speaker: Dorothea,
sp.l: Take the whole fault on thee:
No matter.

sp.speaker: Orontus,
sp.l: All my Prancks will now come forth.

sp.speaker: Lyſet,
sp.l: Now,—am I fifty Dorothea's worth?

sp.speaker: Dorothea,
sp.l: Who was't ſpake with you, when Orontus Knock'd?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: With me?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Yes, you?—believe I'le not be mock'd.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: What do ye take me?—

sp.speaker: Dorothea▪
sp.l: No excuſe, Unleſs—

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Dear Madam,

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Some Gallant

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs.

sp.speaker: Cliton,
sp.l: 'T was one that loves me without complement,
And I love him, faith, with no ill intent.

sp.speaker: Cliton,
sp.l: He'l be my Husband.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: HA! good Hypocrite,
Your Husband.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Cliton.

sp.speaker: Orontus,
sp.stage: to Cliton whilſt he takes the Candle from the Table.
sp.l: Whither with that light?
Say.—

sp.speaker: Cliton,
sp.l: To finde out this Husband ſhe will have,
I'le bring't again, when I have kill'd the ſlave.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Keep back your folly.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Ah! in my diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Take comfort Cliton, that will make it leſs.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: This ſatisfies?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Yes, if you pleaſe, and more.

sp.speaker: Argante,
sp.l: Lycante we are robb'd! ſtand at that door.

sp.speaker: Cliton,
sp.l: Sir,—now w'are caught!

sp.speaker: Dorothea▪
sp.l: O! infinite diſgrace.
My Father comes here, hye away apace.

sp.speaker: To Lyſet.
sp.l: Take up the Candle,—ſlip in here with me.

sp.speaker: To Orontus.
sp.l: Save, you my honour.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Devil, but who ſaves me?
W'are left alone.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: My honour now lies on't
To ſee.—

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Let's fly,—and think no more upon't,
For fear ſome ranting Hector, otherwiſe
Should come, and this love-folly ſo chaſtiſe—.
But—'tis too late.

lg.l: Don't I Orontus ſee?
O Daughrer! whoſe wilde love diſhonours me.
Dye thou vile tempter.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Hold your threatning ſword!

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Before you kill us, good Sir, hear one word!

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: What vain excuſe,—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Mine, is both juſt and true,
For, tho unhappy,—I am guiltleſs too.
Being, fair Lucia's fond idolater,
Her Brother, this night found me there with her.
And having no way left to ſcape him there,
I leap'd his Garden wall, and got in here.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: In ſo ſhort time, I never made more way.

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: I heard ſome ſtir i'th' Garden, as you ſay,
And from my Window, did perceive one go
With haſte enough, who 'twas I could not know.
But, tho there be ſome colour, Sir, in this
Excuſe,—yet ſo great the importance is
To my whole Family, e're I proceed
This truth upon my daughters face I'le read.
Her looks will bring the certainty to light.
I'le ſtraight return. (Argante goes out.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Ah! Sir, bid him good night.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Doeſt fear?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: I? no, but I ſmall courage have:
You, like a Torch i'th' winde, all ſtorms out-brave
And may eſcape, But—(Oh! the Collick gripes.)
Poor Cliton ſhall be ſent to bed with ſtripes.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Hark! for they talk.

sp.speaker: Argante,
sp.stage: ſpeaking to Eraſte, whom he findes in his houſe, and ſhutting the door upon him to prevent his ſeeing of Orontus.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, do you ſtay there.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: He locks this door! Oh! how I quake for fear.

sp.speaker: Argante,
sp.l: Go, Sir, make haſte, for your relation's true.
Your enemy!—I ſhake.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: Does purſue.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Who is't?

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: D'yee ask? Eraſtes.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: —Ha.

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: —Agen?
I met him there.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Then, that's the ſtratagem.
By what ſtrange paths this truth comes in my way.

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: You both are ruin'd if ye longer ſtay.
Make quick diſpatch.

sp.speaker: Orontus,
sp.l: See, Women's fickleneſs.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Take comfort Sir, 'twill make your griefs the leſs. Ex. Oront. Cliton.

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: This danger was prevented well in troth,
I'le ſend this after, then good night to both.

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: ERaſtes.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: Who can gueſs this myſtery?
Surprize me here, yet deal thus lovingly.

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: What brought you here, I pardon, for your ſake;
But no noiſe on't, if you my counſel take;
Upon ſuch accidents, wiſe men ſhould wink.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: Think not.—

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: I know Sir, what I ought to think,

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: I doubt that—

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: No, no, I ſhall let it ſleep.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: Perhaps.—

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: —Be ſure, I ſhall the ſecret keep:
Adieu.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: But—

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: 'Tis high time, be gone I pray.
Make haſte.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: I underſtand not what he'd ſay. (Exit.

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: Tho, now I'm freed, I tremble yet for fear.
How timely theſe by me diſcover'd were,
—Now in the ſtreet, fight, or embrace at eaſe:
Long may they ſcuffle e're it me diſpleaſe.
If they each other drill till I go forth,
Their skins to morrow will be little worth.

div.trailer: The End of the Third ACT.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: HOw ill thou argu'ſt! what, thou thinkeſt then?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: But, Sir, it puzles me above all ken
'Till dooms-day, I might thus be arguing,
Yet ſtill i'th' dark for all my reaſoning.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Confeſs then, I know how one ought to live.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Such are your flights, that none can you retrieve.
For my part, I renounce.—After th' abuſe
You late receiv'd at your two Rendez-vous,
Who would not ſwear, that in your choller, you
Should blinking Cupid curſe,—and his Mam too:
Sigh, groan, ſobb, howl, and tumble all the night,
And from your neſt, in three dayes make no flight;
Your brain's unhing'd, your heart conſum'd with care,
Whereas you ſing and frisk more gay then c're;
Nay, Rant,—and in all company laugh moſt▪
And bear't as you had neither won nor loſt.
Moſt Heteroclite does your carriage ſeem!

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: And wher's the wonder? they leave me,—I them.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: If towards you, ſome Fickleneſs they ſhow,
They but return you back, a quid pro quo.
For Miſtriſs, waiting-Maid, Fair, Black, Red, Brown
You fear no colours, but ſtorm every Town!
Your eager Appetite with all makes bold,
And to your Stomack, none's too hot or cold.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Ther's all the pleaſure that in Love I find!

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: And they begin to love you in your kind.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I'm not diſpleas'd.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Then, muſt I ſay, indeed,
I think your Love's but ſome new baſtard-breed.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: And thus I whip him to my own deſire.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: More I examine, I the more admire,
Sometimes, you play the ſprightly Gallants part;
Then, nought but ſadneſs ſits about your heart.
A Jovial air, 'mongſt theſe disbands all fears;
The next you Court,—you ſoften with your Tears.
So to the life, my ſelf deceiv'd I find.
You, groan, and ſing, and ſigh,—and all's but wind.
What juggling tricks!

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: And this does wonder breed?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: I ne're knew ſuch Cameleon Love indeed,
At each new Face it's hue ſo chang'd to be!

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: This but prevents Love, from in-ſlaving me.
I dare him thus,—make all his Plots prove vain,
So I the pleaſures taſte, without the pain.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: At once to give and take a Heart in jeſt,
Is this Love?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: This is Love, and 'tis the beſt.

sp.speaker: Cliton,
sp.l: But, is not Love, Sir, a controling heat▪
(For I'm a Scholar ſince I ſerv'd Lyſet.)
A frying in the Froſt, freezing in Fire,
Which ſtorms the Brain, and Fetters the Deſire
To one alone; Pleaſing, tho Incomode?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: It was of old,—but, now 'tis out of Mode.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: 'Tis out of Mode!

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: And dull, as ſhall be try'd.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: How muſt we doe, to have it Modify'd?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: My conduct will inſtruct thee in the right.
Examine't well.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: 'Tis beyond my dull ſight.
If you'l inſtruct me, you muſt bring it neer.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Liſten, and the whole ſecret will appear.
"To every She, the like complaiſance pay;
"Swear Love by rote, not minding what you ſay.
"Court out of cuſtome for diverſion's ſake.
"Speak much of grief, but let your heart ne're ake.
"Your Face (the Index) much of Love muſt ſhow;
"But what you promiſe, let your Breaſt not know.
"Of an Un-truth, a Verity compile,
"At need, and weep, (tho in your thoughts you ſmile,)
"Raving of Paſſion, pain, troubles of Mind.
"And not to hazard ought by woman-kind,
"Pay the whole Sex, your Adoration
"In groſs,—but ſingly,—ſlight them one by one.
This is my Rule.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: The Science I approve,
You thus extract the Quinteſſence of Love.
—But,—as for Lyſet, be it underſtood
You take or leave her quite, for both our good.
Otherwiſe.—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Without wrangling,—I yet may
Leave thee ſole Tenant e're we paſs one day.
For now agen Fortune does me provide,
Since Dorothea's true, I'm ſatisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Eraſt' being there hid, tho, ſhew's ſome Ginn?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I know the whole Intrigue.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: From whom?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: —From him.
Who walking home, late, when our Plot was laid,
Paſs'd by their door, where by ſome hazard ſtaid
Finding it open, and ſhe ſtanding by,
Surpriz'd her out of curioſity.
Believing with her Maid,—ſhe had intent
To paſs ſome moments there in merry-ment.
His pleaſing converſe hardly did begin
When he muſt hide,—the Father coming in.
And, now, what ſcruple can there be in this?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Born under ſome Smock Star.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: —The beſt on't is,
Florame, that ſought who held Eraſtes heart,
Found Dorothea claim'd his Siſters part.
When, he expreſſing by what rigour they
Forcing his will, tore him from Lucia:
So won upon him, he conſent did ſpeak,
Provided they the firſt Contract would break.
They ſtraight embrace, and both this Match approve,
Which turns their hate into a nobler Love.
Thus Florame and Eraſtes are agreed
To baniſh Fewd, and let kind Peace ſucceed.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: So Florame, now, his promiſe has obtain'd?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Th'rough my endeavour, full conſent was gain'd.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: You'l no more ſee her?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I!—as oft as e're.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: She ſooths you ſtill with flat' ring hopes, I fear▪
And while ſhe to another deſtin'd is,
Makes you.—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Did I not think as much as this
Of Dorothea yeſterday?—yet I
Miſtook.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: This gulls you more apparently▪

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Why I may erre as much in this perchance▪

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Sure you believe Florame.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: He does advance.
Now I ſhall know the truth, how he proceeds▪

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: YOu'r ſatisfy'd, I hope, now all ſucceeds?

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: Yes,—but to gain the brother will not do
Alone,—Your help is neceſſary too.
In vain,—I thought the other Match unknown,
Since Fame the News o're all this place hath blown;
And with fair Lucia ſo much credit gain'd,
She ſwears my flames for her, are only feign'd.
But,—you,—whoſe friendſhip dives into my heart,
And knows its cloſeſt Projects, take my part;
Wait on that Beauty,—Wooe her not to ſhun
Such real Love,—Compleat what you begun.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Is not this Raillery you ſpeak,—tell true?
If you love Lucia, does not ſhe love you?
To give you meeting e're Eraſt conſent,
Does make her Love appear moſt Evident:
Yet you ſuſpect? Ah! what muſt I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Cliton,
sp.l: How ſlyly does he ſqueeze the worm from's Noſe.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: Since to hide ought from you, a crime I deem,
Know her love yet, reſides but in eſteem.
And that appointment, you ſo happy gueſs,
To confidence, had ow'd for it's ſucceſs.
Since I th'rough favour had in vain aſſay'd:
And then with Preſents had ſuborn'd her Maid;
Who, ſtill unknown to her, engag'd laſt night
To gain me admittance to her ſight.
This was the reaſon, made me think it vain,
Head-long to run, where was more loſs then gain:
You otherwiſe had ne're diſſwaded me.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Good-faith, I thought 'twas better then I ſee.
But—having gain'd what was moſt difficult,
The Oracle we need no more conſult.
The Victory is Ours,—I'le bring't about.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: You being Second, 'tis a ſin to doubt.
Mean while, I'le try what is her temper, now
Her Brother's ours, and what hope ſhe'l allow.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: WEll Cliton.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: I conceive.—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: 'Twas I conceiv'd
The right.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Your doubt.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Had me deceiv'd.
Lucia is wholly yours—ſay what they can,
For Politiques you are a dreadful man!
And if that Devil, who writeth your ſins down,
Omits not One, h'as a ſhrewd head on's own.
W'are Stratagems who lies within your pow'r.
Lucia, in fine.—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I'le love more from this hour.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: ,Tis well, and Dorothea.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: More and more.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Then, ſure, you'l quickly give poor Lyſet o're.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Yes, ſhe's too lean a thing to ſatisfie:
She may paſs Muſter in a vacancy,
For want of better.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Better!—ah ſpeak well.
A Goat, ſet Horns aſide, would her excel.
If ſhe paſs Muſter, 'tis for want indeed!

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: TRuly, Sir, Cliton's Manners now exceed.
The Dev'l, lay's horns away, like thee'd appear. (to Cliton.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Now I am muzled.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Leave that Puppy there,
Who jealous cauſe I love thee,—thus the Elf
Would black thee?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Love me?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Yes, in-troth, thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Cliton,
sp.l: Mark but the Juggler.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Thus.—

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: —On Cliton's faith.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Go, go, I heard too well.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: What is't ſhe ſaith?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Ther's want indeed, when I can Muſter paſs.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: I ſung a Mean,—and you interpret Baſe.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: If you give ear, he'l ne're have done his part.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Command me.—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Silence.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Now begins his Art.
Lay on, my back is broad.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Still dear Lyſet
My real love does little faith beget.
In thy long abſence, I have torments try'd.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: I muſt believ't.

sp.speaker: Cliton,
sp.l: Ware being Noblyfy'd.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: My pleaſant humour thinks all's Raillery;
But falſely you believe 'tis flattery.
For when an object, like thee, charms this breaſt,
I think on't more then once.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: And love't at l 〈…〉
I'le help ye out.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Ah! thus to doubt my flame!
Is.—

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: No, I think I highly cheriſh'd am.
But ſince your Love with me's but left in pawn;
'Tis ten to one it will be ſoon with-drawn.
My Miſtreſs—.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Thou believ'ſt ſhe blows my Fire?
Go, if my heart to ſerve her e're aſpire,

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Laſt Night, you ſaw her, then, for the laſt time?
