sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Drawn for thy ſake, that Obligation's thine▪

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Mine?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Doſt thou doubt?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Moſt like you, Sir, it is.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: What, not believe?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Yes, I know more then this.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Prethee, once more, my Oath upon it take,
I went laſt Night but only for thy ſake,
Her entertainment's hateful to my ear;
But having learn'd thy Reſidence was there,
Tho ſure to have that odious Object by
I ran, in hopes to Woe thee with my Eye.
That Language Lovers ever held the beſt.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: How you'r compos'd of Subtilty and Jeſt.
You found her tho, alone.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: At which being ſad,
I ſtudy'd in Revenge to make her Mad;
Paid her Reſpects were much more ſtrange, then true,
Contemn'd, her moſt, when I moſt Prais'd her too.
But my high Style, loſt her in the Mid-way.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: You may repair that fault again to day.
She muſt ſpeak with you. This I'me ſent to tell.
Make haſte, and follow.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Thou love'ſt Mirth ſo well▪

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Faith,—ſhe expects you, and will let you know
When you come there.—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I'le not conſent to go.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: You muſt,—What will you make her elſe ſuſpect,
That I omit her Meſſage, th'rough neglect?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I ſhall have much adoe.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: I'le take your part▪

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I'm loath to go, I ſpeak it from my Heart,
And I believe you think ſo,—ſeriouſly;
But at the Enter-view, obſerve my Eye.
At the leaſt word of Love, look you on me
And what I ſay to her,—take all for thee.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: I ſhall not fail,—'tis done,—do but proceed

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: You Jibe?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Like you.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Faith I Love thee, indeed
And to make good, in thy Society
My deareſt Pleaſures Sov'raign Bliſs does lie.
That thy commands are my chief glory, too,
Here—

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: You at length, may make me think all true,

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Time, will diſcover, what as yet lies hid

sp.speaker: Cliton,
sp.l: My Nobleneſs goes on, the Price is bid.
I cannot hold.—Hola!
sp.stage: Cliton crys out with a ſhrill voice.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: —What Devil's Cry?

sp.speaker: Cliton, to Orontus.
sp.l: 'Gainſt all Events, having a Remedy,
Vouchſafe one Favour, now my Heart's ſo ſad?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: What i'ſt?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Sir, keep me pray from running Mad!

sp.speaker: Orontus,
sp.l: If—but, who's this I ſee?

sp.speaker: Cliton,
sp.l: —Good,—here's relief

sp.speaker: Lyſet,
sp.l: Ah! he put's up his Purſe agen, the Thief!

sp.speaker: Orontus,
sp.l: What e're I ſay,—let it create no doubt,
Wee'l laugh anon.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Now, I muſt ſtand it out.
Hopes of his preſent does invite my ſtay.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: BLeſt with your Preſence, once more Lucia.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: A common joy,—But with regret, Sir, I
Thus interrupt your wiſhed Secreſie.
Surely you treated with great Confidence.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: What, you ſuſpect I held Intelligence.
And think deſign, what accidental proves?
Cliton knows.—

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Yes, he's honeſt, where he Loves.
Though this freſh▪ Object, to my ſhame, I ſee—

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: He Courted her, indeed, but 'twas for me,

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: If you believe that Fool—

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: What I behold,
I dare believe,—but not all I am told.

sp.speaker: Crontus.
sp.l: Then on your part, my Ruine is aſſur'd?

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: What Perſecution, I for you indur'd.
Whilſt a harſh Brother for Florame, this day—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I more deſerve then he,—ſo to obey.
Much your own loſs, and prejudice would be,
And you oblige your ſelf, whilſt juſt to me.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Take heed! leaſt this preſumption to reprove,
I yield him up—at laſt—my faith and love!

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: 'Tis but three ſighs more, added to the heap.
But,—e're you do't conſult, look e're you leap.
And get your heart's conſent to it before

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: What! would my loſs affect you then no more?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: What? you'l betray your ſelf, and therefore I
Muſt yield my ſelf a prey to grief—and dye!
Let it ſting thoſe it does moſt nearly touch.
Grief almoſt kill'd me laſt night 'twas ſo much;
For having known how well Florame was us'd
By you, I haſted to you much confus'd:
There wept and wail'd, and all ſad means did try,
Low at your feet, to break this heart and dye.
But ſince I finde it inconvenient prove,
I'le blow it off, and try new faſhion love.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Your faſhion,—to deceive, and be ingrate.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: That love's moſt pleaſing, is leaſt delicate,
And where we once reſolve, no Jealouſie,
Should

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Without reaſon then it ceazes me?
Nor may I credit give to my own eyes.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: You ſhould paſs by ſuch things, if you were wiſe.
Let's make the agreement thus, 'twixt you and me:
To have no jealous thoughts,—but ever free
From all vain fears, think either's faith moſt true,
And if you ne're doubt me, I'le ne're doubt you.
Thus when I ſwear, believ't I love you well:
I'le do the ſame, when you Love-ſtories tell▪
All this obſerv'd, our Contract ſhall remain;
But the leaſt tripp, infringes it again.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: True love, ſublim'd, will all this diſavow,
He makes a Monſter on't, does this allow.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Allowing what we like, but makes us find
The troubles leſs,—pleaſures more un-confin'd.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: No, he that can divided Love indure,
And not dye rather, has ſmall courage ſure?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: If, in effect, this Maxime bare the ſway,
Men were in danger to dye every day.
Can any lightneſs with your own compare,
Laſt night one,—now another,—ſo y'all are.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: The better to delude us, thus ye plead:
But, think how many th'rough ſuch grief are dead.
And oft have had the applauſe of learned men.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: The' example's dang'rous, I renounce it then.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Your heart's too cold, where ſuch brave dangers are.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Let, who's will do't, and take my honours ſhare.
Should I expire your Martyr,—for a day
Or two, perhaps, the world ſhould hear you ſay
He was a Faithful Lover,—I regret
For me he dy'd!—Much I by this ſhould get.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Is an an illuſtrious Memory no gain?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Heav'ns grant my Epitaph leſs ſad, and vain!

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: And yet you'l ſay; you love men'eretheleſs.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Ask but my heart, my heart which you poſſeſs.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. VI.
div.stage: ORONTUS, ERASTES, LUCIA, LYSET. CLITON, LYSTOR.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes,
sp.l: THey do adore each other,—I am told.

sp.speaker: Lucia,—
sp.l: My Brother's here,—O Gods!

sp.speaker: Eraſtes▪
sp.l: I ſee him,—hold!

sp.speaker: Lyſtor.
sp.l: A Lady with him.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: Then it muſt be ſhe▪
'Tis Dorothea.

sp.speaker: Lucia
sp.l: Think of leaving me.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes—
sp.l: This night with her, he through the Garden went;
I know her—

sp.speaker: Orontus,
sp.l: What? and muſt I then conſent?

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Yes, for I dare not go, till after you;
Pray loſe no time, be gone,—bid me adieu.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I do obey you.—Cliton!

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Sir, what now?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Stop Lyſet here, but ſtop her mouth cloſe too,
Promiſe her any thing,—do't e're you ſtir.

div.stage: Orontus goes off one way, and immediately Lucia goes another.

sp.speaker: Lyſtor,
sp.l: She goes

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: Ingrateful! but I'le follow her.
For without doubt, her woman does abide,
That if we ask who 'tis, ſhe be deny'd.
But, following after, I her plots deſtroy.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: HOw ſhall I act the part of th' angry Boy?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Cliton.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: No quarter.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Such ſevere ill will?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Provide elſewhere.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Do'ſt keep thy anger ſtill
Cliton?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Yes ſtill I keep't, and keep it ſhall.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Look up?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: —No.—

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: But—

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: I'le bate thee nought at all.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: What you'l forſake me,—You, whoſe grizled Pate,
And ſnuffling Noſe, proclaims ye out of date?
You will forſake me,—Me, who more or leſs,
The whole Town dotes on, for my prettineſs.
Me, whoſe dear Love ſo hotly they purſue,
It makes them look on Thee, with envy too.
Who thus abaſe my thoughts.—

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Yes,—you,—you,—you?
Who ſqueez'd my Purſe, and then laugh'd at me too.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Your gifts, I'le warrant, Trick me up thus brave.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Pox, Now I apprehend this Female knave. (aſide.
Before my face, your liberty's ſo bold
'T has made my wonted charity catch cold.
—Ev'ry one Courts you now.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: —Yes, and thoſe words
Alone a daily Revenue affords▪

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: And this to me, you think muſt comfort bring?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Cliton, ſpeak wiſely, and leave quarrelling.
You knew my humour, and my Method knew,
That I lov'd cloathes in faſhion,—often new.
Each day I purchaſe ſomewhat, and proteſt
What I do cut or ſow,—is of the beſt
Either the Draper or the Mercer ſells.
And whilſt my Caſh holds, I do little elſe.
Now,—think what this muſt coſt? For, to go neat;
Wiſhing, nor Witch-craft, will not do the feat:
Your Wages, whatſoever,—hardly brings
Enough for Gloves, and ſuch ſmall trifling things.
So that to prove too Coy, would prove my ſhame,
My Pride would fall,—And then Adieu—Fine Dame.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: 'Tis right,—but come—to wave all you have ſaid,
What have I reap'd for all my Wages paid?
From day to day, my Paſſion has encreaſt;
Yet with my finger ne're durſt feel your—Breaſt.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: I lov'd thee,—that's ſufficient I conceive.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Lov'd me!

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: To doubt, your ſelf were to deceive;
You know.

sp.speaker: Cliton,
sp.l: I'm left in Hell, Loves Barly-break▪

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Does not ſix ſighes a Day, my true love ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Great comfort that, to troubled Souls does prove.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Do you ſo light eſteem thoſe mark's of Love?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Juſt next to nothing, ſo I find,—And ſure,
Since Love was ever held an Epicure
And glutton, when the Boy you thus do Treat,
Sighes cannot nouriſh th'are ſuch hollow Meat.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: I loſe my time here, you but love to prate;
And thy weak reaſon turns my love to hate.
Adieu.—

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: But ſtay, if not for Love, for Gold;
For twenty Crowns, can you One Secret hold?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: One, yes a ſcore.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Hold! that's too much for Thee!

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: I'le do't, I'le warrant, let it reſt on me.
Can you disburſe-em?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Yes,—but prethee hear!
Keep but your Tongue, out of your Miſtriſs' Ear.
My Maſter.—

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: I'le conceal his Prancks,—ne're doubt.
Let's ſee the Money?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: 'Tis not yet told out.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Your promiſes on hopes, will ill ſucceed.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: I'le pawn my Honour.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: A fair pledge indeed.
Go, I'le diſcover all that ever paſt.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Beware he do not Nooze you, too, at laſt.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: AT leaſt defer it, till my troubled mind
Compos'd,—to this ſad Hymen be inclin'd.
Do not precipitate—

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: You hope in vain▪
By pray'r to blaſt, my juſt deſign again:
Yours I perceive, I read it in your ſoul:
But Florames Father now has my Parol,
Which I muſt keep,—he claims you thereupon,
And ſo to morrow Hymen makes you One▪

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: But he ſo little values me, you ſee
He hardly.—

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: That, but an effect may be
Of what's reported, by Orontus, who
Is ſaid to have pretences for you to.
Florame alarm'd therewith, does colder prove,
Fearing his Rival, more then him you love.
From his diſturbed thoughts I gather it,
Which ſince a miſ-report does thus beget,
I ought to haſten on this Nuptial Tye,
To ſet all right, and them to ſatisfy.
Think on't, Adieu.—I'le to his Fathers run,
And there conſult what more is to be done. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dorothea,
sp.l: In vain this Man, for Husband you'd prefer;
My Eyes herein, ſhall be my Counſeller.
But, Lyſet comes, Love take thou my defence.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: I Staid thy coming with impatience.
Well,—is he found, what's his reply, tell true?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: I have at once both found and loſt him too.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: How, did he ſlight the Meſſage thou didſt tell?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: You do not know him yet; ſure, very well.
He's too much vers'd in's way to blanch at that.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Then prethee let me know how 'tis, and what?
Didſt ſay I wait him?—Shall I ſee him here?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: No doubt he'l come,—but pray beware a ſnare.
If you'l believe me, give him word for word;
Pay him in's own coine, but no more afford.
Engage no farther, then you find him go.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: What does induce thee to ſpeak of him ſo?
Is he inconſtant, falſe?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: That ſhall appear,
Be Judge your ſelf, pray, Madam do but hear.
I'th' ſtreet I met him in a certain place,
Who ſmiling, when he firſt beheld my Face,
Approach'd me with ſuch joy, as made me deem
His Love was noble, and deſerv'd eſteem.
This did his words confirm, for he did ſay,
He ever would to you obedience pay.
Scarce were theſe words pronounc'd, when I proteſt
A Lady coming,—Here's the main oth' jeſt,—
—He without why, or wherefore, durſt preſume
To ſing her the ſame Song, to the ſame Tune:
And without bluſhing, tho I ſtood cloſe by,
Diſcours'd of Love to her moſt pleaſantly.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Unworthy Man,—had he the confidence
Before your Face to own a new pretence,
And mention Love to her?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Yes, in my ſight.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Diſſembling Traytor!

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: 'Tis his whole delight.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: But, then the Lady, what became of her?
Go on.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: A long while they did there confer,
When, ſuddenly, ('twas plotted I dare ſay)
They part, and each retir'd a ſeveral way.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: And you ne're follow'd to enquire her name?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: I would, and much I long'd to know the ſame;
But, then Orontus ſervant made me ſtand,
Who having pop't ſome Sweet-meats in my hand,
In earneſt of ſome better thing e're long,
Promis'd me Mountains for to hold my tongue:
But I,—what do you think I am ſo baſe?
Then throwing all the Sweet-meats in his face,
Sirra (cry'd I)—I'le ne're prove falſe for theſe,

l.hi: Nor do I uſe to ſell my Miſtriſſes▪
If I need Money, ſhe ſuch plenty hath
In ſtore for me, I need not break my Faith.

sp.l: Then did my courage prompt me to engage.—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Thy Zeal does raviſh me.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: I ſwell'd with rage.
What, I betray you?—Sell you? Wher's his wit?
He proffer.—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Go,—thou ſhalt not loſe by it.
In the mean time, ſee my unhappy Fate?
And with what reaſon I did all men hate:
Since this Orontus, for whoſe Love,—my Pride
And noble Haughtineſs I laid aſide;
Like a Diſſembler does me ſlight and brave,
And puts on others Chains, who was my ſlave.
But,—truly this was timely brought to light,
Ere I conſulted that falſe Man to night;
Or how to break this other Hymen ask't
Advice.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: You hope in vain, ther's promiſe paſt:
Your Father urges it, and having pow'r.

sp.speaker: Dorothea,
sp.l: Let him urge ſtill, I'le quaſh all in one hour.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: But Florame has his word, his heart, his love.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Florame, at need, my help herein would prove,
Since to endeavour this our union he
Too much averſion ever met in me.
In vain theſe impotent old Parents try
Upon our wills to act their tyranny.
Each others coldneſs being mutual,
We dread not their authority at all.
But,—who is't locks that door? what is't they do?

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: PRotect me, from a brother does purſue
To finde me out,—whoſe wrath and jealouſie
For walking forth, will harſhly light on me.
In vain, by twenty turns, from ſtreet to ſtreet
I ſought to ſteal away, and he not ſee't.
He follow'd ſtill, and keeping me in ſight
Conſtrain'd me now, leſt on me he ſhould light
To ſtep in here, where I your aid implore.
For ſhelter, till—this danger may blow o're.
See who 'tis begs. (ſhe takes off her Hood.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Ah! Lucia is it thee?

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: 'Tis I, whoſe cruel Brothers jealouſie—
But, there he knocks,—to ſave me from his frown
Pray, feign you juſt now come in from the Town.
My Hood, I'le leave you.
sp.stage: ſhe puts her hood upon Dorotheas head.

sp.speaker: Dorothea
sp.l: Hide you quickly, do.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: In here!

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Dy'e know?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Open the door, go, go.
Make haſte.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: No matter, ſhe ſhall make it good.

sp.speaker: Dorothea,
sp.l: What will he think on't?

sp.speaker: Dorothea,
sp.stage: giving her Hood to Lyſet as if ſhe newly came into the houſe.
sp.l: LYſet, take my Hood.
sp.stage: Lyſet goes out with the Hood, and enters agen about the latter end of the Scene.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: Pardon th' intruſion; you may well ſuſpect,
Void both of Love to you, and of reſpect.
I follow my diſpair, and with much pain
The ſtorms of my juſt anger now refrain.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Your humour's much diſturb'd to day, I find:
I thought ſo ſmooth a Calm raign'd in your mind,
That ſtill immoveable at all events,
Your ſoul no anger knew, nor diſcontents.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: None, but for you, caus'd by my too great Faith
And Love—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Then I'm the object of this wrath.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: Deny, ungratefully you ſcorn my flame;
Deny, my Rivals happineſs, your ſhame;
What yet I ſaw, muſt treaſon be confeſt?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Believe me, Sir, you rave!

sp.speaker: Eraſtis.
sp.l: But yet, at leaſt
You will agree, ſince many eyes did ſee't,
You held diſcourſe with him in th' open ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: Whom I follow'd after your adieu's,
Believe—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Your eyes.—

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: Theſe eyes ne're bring falſe newes▪
But clearly to evince, and tell your ſhame,
It will ſuffice, when I Orontus name.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Orontus!

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: Yes,—that Gallant was there, to,
Whom you gave audience while he courted you.
Can you deny it ſtill?

sp.speaker: Dorothea,
sp.l: In troth 'tis fine,
I ſerve my Rival,—was ere Fate like mine?

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: Your ſilence is confeſſion.—All deſires
I henceforth baniſh, quenching all my Fires.
A moſt Unfaithful She, I did adore;
But Heav'ns diſcovery bids my heart give o're.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: This is too raſh,—yet ſtill my goodneſs ſee?
(For ſure you neither know, nor ſpeak to me.)
I pardon your blind rage, tho gone ſo far
As to miſtake both me, and who you are▪
Think on me, whilſt your tongue you fiercely whet,
And think how much you do your ſelf forget.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: I've thought too long, and Juſtly have accus'd—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: What you proceed?—This makes me more confus'd,
Your words ſo diſcompos'd at randome fly.
—But, pray, let's know, what makes you ſpeak thus high?
Orontus, ſay you, hath my heart obtain'd.
Is it a Crime that Man my love hath gain'd?
What had I promis'd you, ſhould hinder me?
I brake no Oaths, nor Vows, my ſoul was free,
If from one Letter, you this inf'rence make,
Your eaſineſs that favour did miſtake.
I love to jeaſt, if that will do the deed,
I'de write a hundred more ſuch for a need.
That Paper ſhew'd in Mirth I much delight,
And you will find ſo, if you ſpell it right.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: What, mock me thus?—Is this the fruit at laſt
Of all my hopes, and all my ſervice paſt?
After two years, ſpent in devoirs and love?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Such devoirs ſometimes do but trouble prove.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: Now your proud minde does caſt off all diſguiſe.
This ſhews my error, and unſeals my eyes;
Go, take your ſwinge in your unconſtant will.
Leave me,—and live for your Orontus ſtill.
Thoſe fetters once ſo ſoft and dear, I break,
And to keep nothing that of you does ſpeak.
That Letter, whoſe allurements made me burn,
Tho once my treaſure I will back return.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: You will oblige me, do, kinde Sir, 'tis fit▪

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: Yes, I'le reſtore it, make no doubt of it.
I'le haſte home for it, Madam, ſtay that while. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: IN fine; heaven now begins on you to ſmile,
The Rival Lady,—ſhe to whom I ſaid
The falſe Orontus new addreſſes made
Is in your power, what more could fortune do?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: I know, yet have maintain'd her quarrel too.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: I ſuffer'd hitherto, but now ſhe muſt,

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Speak ſoftly, elſe ſhe hears, and may diſtruſt.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: I'le warrant her from being now ſo near,
She fled into the Garden out of fear.
And to return you thanks there waits thus long.
I came now thence.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: T' avenge my love and wrong,
And blaſt his baſe deſign, this remedy
I quickly;—ſtay—what's that appears to me?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Lyſet.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: 'Tis Cliton.—Is your Maſter there? (to Cliton.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: May he come in?

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: But—

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Let him not fear,
The good man's forth, tell him. (Cliton goes out.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: See now Lyſet.
How both of them do fall into my net.
If from diſdain of me their love take root,
One ſtroke may lop them both, and I will do't.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Let not fierce jealouſie bear ſo great a ſway,
But ſeek—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Go back, and finde out Lucia.
And when you gueſs Orontus may be here
Lead her this way, till ſhe approach ſo near,
That having ſtopt her, on ſome other ſcore
She may hear all we ſay, from yonder door,
His tongue muſt prate of Love when he comes in,
And I'le return as good as he can bring.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: The bait's ſo tempting—he will bite anon.
I think I hear him. (Exit.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Quickly then, be gone▪
He's here.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: HOw Sir?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I tell thee, I, in fine
Have quitted her, and Lyſet's henceforth thine.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: In earneſt?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: And in earneſt ſhall be ſtill.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Thank's Sir—Now puſh your fortunes where you will.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: How dear ſoever I this favour prize,
Yet, from your goodneſs this regret does riſe.
That here expected by you, it may chance
Breed doubt which brings me, love—or complaiſance
For your commands may ſeem to make it prove
More my obedience then an act of love.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.stage: appearing at the door with Lucia, whom ſhe obliges to retire a ſtep or two.
sp.l: Madam, a Gentleman is there you ſee.
Stay.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: 'Tis Orontus, Ah! falſe man, 'tis he!

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: While you ſurprize me by your Complement
With art enough, you my complaints prevent.
But, ſay your ſelf, what ſhall I now believe?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: My Joy's ſo great, you may the truth perceive.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: I doubt 'tis art.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Small reaſon in this caſe.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: A treacherous ſoul oft hath a ſmiling face.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: To be ſecure, this a ſafe way will prove,
Ask your own heart, that knows how I do love.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: It owns no ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: More then you confeſs,
Vouchſafe to hear it, it will ſpeak no leſs.
Beſides which, my Devoirs my love ſets forth.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Which being forc'd, are but of little worth.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: The Homage paid thoſe Eyes, which rule my heart,
Are they eſteem'd a force then, on your part?
That love which no ſelf-intereſts defile,
That has no droſs, no mixture, nought that's vile.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: You ſet it highly forth.

sp.speaker: Orontus,
sp.l: Have I not cauſe,
Since 'tis your Vertue only gives it lawes?
Your worth, the only motive comprehends,
Of my true love,—And ſuch love's without ends.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: I may preſume it then, to be long liv'd;
This rare, this noble birth from me deriv'd;
For though, the pow'r of time moſt pow'rful be,
Can that e're make me ceaſe from being me?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: It were great wrong both to my Faith and Will,
To doubt my Love were not immortal ſtill.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: You ſpeak ſo laviſhly, I juſtly fear,
Leaſt ſome ſurprizal you intended here.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Does my Sincerity ſuſpicion give?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: They hazard much, that lightly do believe▪

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Hopes founded on great Merits, may be ſaid
By being limited to be betraid.
Such ought from ſo firm rules not to depart,
Which lays a claim to every noble heart.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: From thence it comes, ſoon as your Eyes give fire
You conquer ev'ry object you deſire.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: From hence it is with little fear I do
See others under-hand, attempting you.
I ſerve you out of love,—Eraſtes out
Of gain,—your Eye-ſight's good, what need I doubt?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Your merits do preſage you cannot fail,
Set againſt him, you muſt o'reweigh the ſcale.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Go as it will, my ſelf I'le ſatisfy.
Thoſe ſhall deſerve my care, that will comply:
Or if another choice they ſhall purſue,
Th'rough their own folly.—My Faith bids adieu.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Such weakneſs in my choice ſhall never be;
This fly reproach is it addreſs'd to me?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Your lov's too ſcrupulous, I'le tell yee true.
Such general terms, do not reflect on you.
—But, I hear noiſe!

sp.speaker: Dorothea,
sp.l: Where is't?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: You ſeem to fear,
And look—

sp.speaker: Dorothea▪
sp.l: I look't about for Lyſet here.
I thought I ſaw her.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: So you might. I ſay—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: What is become of her?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: She's gone this way;
I'le go and call her.

sp.speaker: Dorothea,
sp.l: Gods! what would you do?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Shew a ſmall proof, of my great Zeal for you.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Still with your Love ſuſpicion does appear.
But, know, if any perſon were hid there
Without my leave, perhaps my woman may—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: That you are guilty, Madam, who dares ſay?
This time you ſpeak againſt your ſelf, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: I've cauſe to fear your prying jealouſie
Since yeſterday you ſtuck the ſame reproach.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Pray do but cauſe your woman to approach.

sp.speaker: Dorothea,
sp.l: And under that pretence your doubts begin
To—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Then permit—

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Eraſtes is within.
Put on Sir, make the naked truth appear;
Perhaps 'tis Lyſets t'other Husband's there!

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Well, do your pleaſure, Sir, but after this.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Y'are much allarm'd.—Lyſet!

sp.speaker: Lucia,
sp.stage: diſcovering her ſelf ſuddenly to Orontus.
sp.l: AH! here ſhe is!
Take courage man, Fate cannot be withſtood.

sp.speaker: Cliton,
sp.l: Cheapners enough,—this Market muſt be good.

sp.speaker: Orontus,
sp.l: What unexpected Lab'rinth am I in!

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Your Wit's a Clue, will guide you out agin.

sp.speaker: Lucia,
sp.l: Well, Faithleſs Lover?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.,
sp.l: Lover ſo untrue!

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: What turn by turn your heart thus ſhar'd 'twixt two?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Inconſtant!

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Perjur'd!

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Scornful!

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Flat' • ing!—Nay—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Ungrateful!

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Traytor!

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Have yee more to ſay?

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: After ſo many Vows, without pretence—

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Maſter, for fear o'th' worſt, let's ee'n pack hence:
Should theſe fly on's, as ſome ſhe Dragons do;
Adieu, Gallants, to Man and Mounſir too.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: In fine, the truth, in ſpite of all your skill—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Pray, let me hear th' Inditement, if you will?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Can you demand, yet, what your Crime ſhould be?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Yes, having not the gift of Propheſie.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Deny theſe Treaſons, are ſo Evident,
Shews you not falſer now, then impudent.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Do not paſs ſentence, e're you name the Crime.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: You never told me, that your heart was mine?
That you thoſe Oaths and Vows would ne're forget?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I'le ſwear all this agen, I love ye yet,

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Can you love her, falſe Man, ſo oft did ſay,
Nay ſwear, your heart did yeild to Lucia?
And that—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: All this I'le ſtill make good, and more.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Love me?
Yes, you

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: And me?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I ſtill adore.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Mark but his confidence, though both are by?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: In vain my love for you, I ſhould deny,
Too well you know me not to claim a part.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Why Court you me then, if ſhe have your heart?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: For love.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: —What love?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: —True love

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: True love,—how ſo?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Why, true love, Madam, does from Reaſon flow.
And Reaſon tells me whereſoe're I ſee
Beauty (like pow'r) it muſt adored be.
Thus whilſt in each of you ſuch Charms I meet,
I equally am drawn to baits ſo ſweet.
Nor can you blame me for't, ſince whilſt I do
Her beauty prize, I pay your's worſhip too.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: But, ſince you firſt, or laſt, muſt chuſe, let's ſee
Who you'l prefer?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: That ſtill muſt ſecret be.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Come, come, you muſt declare.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: No,—for in brief
I fear the ſhe I leave would dye for grief.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Sir, you may chuſe elſewhere, as you like beſt▪
Truly, you well deſerve all this conteſt.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Nay, if you'r thus indiffrent. Here I'le vow
My conſtant Love. I'm Dorotheas now.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: The mighty prize I yeild with willing mind.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Had I declar'd for you, youl'd ſpeak more kind.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Her Fortunes great, it cannot be deny'd.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Diſgrace is ſtill attended with falſe Pride.
And yet the loſs perhaps breeds trouble too.
You to whom henceforth, all my love is due,
Believe—

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: This ſudden change admits of doubt.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Your Wit, on ſecond thoughts will make it out.
Since your more great deſerts doe you prefer.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Your various humour makes me fear you erre.
You ſwear to every one.

sp.speaker: Orontus,
sp.l: The Mode,—you ſee:
But as I am,—try how you like of me?

div.head: ACT. V. SCEN. IX.
div.stage: ARGANTE, ORONTUS, FLORAME, ERASTES, DOROTHEA, LUCIA, LYSET, CLITON.

sp.speaker: Eraſtes,
sp.stage: coming in before Argante, ſpeaking to Dorothea.
sp.l: HEre is your Letter, which I would alledge,
—But—how—my Siſter here?

sp.speaker: Argante,
sp.l: Her faith I'le pledge,
I'm Father.

sp.speaker: Florame.
sp.l: O! but rather then conſtrain—
Your coldneſs gives me juſt cauſe to complain.
If falſe repotts alone diſturb your mind;
Or cauſe Orontus, you in preſence find:
Know, that which brings him's Lucia's love, for I—

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: Sir, what you ſpeak of me, I muſt deny.
My love's beyond Orontus hopes ſo far—

sp.speaker: Elorame,
sp.l: Then ſuffer me, at this time to declare,
That having dar'd at Lucia's Bed to aim,
The honour of your Sonſhip would be vain.
Nor can I, Sir, accept of it at laſt.
But here's Eraſtes—

sp.speaker: Eraſtes.
sp.l: No the Dyce is caſt;
To love that falſe One, I ſhall ne're accord.
But, Sir, to you, that I may keep my word,
Lead home my Siſter—You th' effect ſhall ſee.

sp.speaker: Florame,
sp.l: Adieu,—Don't envy my proſperitie.

sp.speaker: Argante,
sp.l: WHat means all this; Does Lucia Florame love?
And is not ſhe the object you approve;
With whom this night caught in your Love deſign,
You leap'd their Garden wall, and came to mine?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Sir,—'tis high time, I ſhould you diſabuſe;
Know therefore, only Love ſhap'd that Excuſe.

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: What meet my Girle by night▪ and both to dare—

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: Pray make no trouble.

sp.speaker: Argante.
sp.l: You ſhall Marry her.

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I muſt conſent to Wed at laſt, for I
Have no way elſe to End this Comedy?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Bring you to Marriage! Who could this fore-ſhow?

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: This ends my Part, and it muſt needs be ſo.

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Yet the Concluſion will imperfect be;
To wind up all, Lyſet ſhould Marry me.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Do'ſt love her?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: I dye for her.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Then ſhe's thine.

sp.speaker: Cliton,
sp.l: My pretty One—

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Not yet,—the choice is mine;
Canſt thou maintain me, like a Dam'ſel fair?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: Yes, ſure.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Haſt thou wherewith?

sp.speaker: Cliton.
sp.l: —Take you no care▪

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Who will ſecure me?

sp.speaker: Cliton,
sp.l: He,

sp.speaker: Orontus.
sp.l: I'le do't,—give o're.

sp.speaker: Lyſet.
sp.l: Firſt lets the Money Count,—Then I'le ſay more.
